title: Mushroom Collection in WA
text:
This interactive map shows mushroom collection zones across Washington, including National Forests, State Parks, Tribal Lands, and National Parks. Hover over or click a region to see collection status, seasonal limits, and additional information provided by the managing agencies.
Below the map, a detailed table expands on the information shown when hovering over regions. Use the search boxes to filter by forest, district, or permit type, and export the data for reference.

⚠️ Important Disclaimers

Collection regulations can change: The information presented here is intended for educational purposes and may not reflect the most current rules. The authors of this site are not responsible for any inaccuracies or changes in mushroom collection regulations.
Safety first: Do not eat wild mushrooms unless positively identified by a qualified expert. Many mushrooms are toxic or deadly.
Respect the land: Always follow guidelines for sustainable collection and respect private, tribal, and protected lands.







 
Below is a detailed table that expands on the information shown when hovering over regions in the map above. You can search, filter, and export the table for reference.

title: Database of Washington Fungi
text:
Welcome to the Fungi of Washington Project!
Explore the incredible diversity of fungi across Washington state, from common mushrooms in city parks to rare species in remote forests. This interactive website is designed to help students, researchers, and the public:

Browse Recorded Species: Search and explore detailed information on hundreds of fungal species, including taxonomy, ecology, and collection records.
View Mushroom Collection Zones: Use the interactive map to see where mushroom collection is allowed, restricted, or requires a permit across national forests, state parks, and tribal lands.
Access Species Fact Sheets: Click on a species’ scientific name to view a dedicated page with images, ecological notes, and references.
Download Data: Filter and export species information for educational or research purposes.

Important Note: Collection regulations and ecological information may change over time. Always check current guidelines and consult an expert before handling or consuming wild mushrooms. This project is intended for educational purposes and does not replace official guidance.

title: Hydnellum peckii
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Hydnellum peckii
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Hydnellum peckii
Synonyms / Former Names: Calodon diabolus, Calodon peckii, Hydnellum diabolus
Common Name(s): strawberries and cream, the bleeding Hydnellum, the bleeding tooth fungus, the red-juice tooth, the devil’s tooth.
Taxonomic Authority / Citation: Hydnellum peckii  Banker, 1912
Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family):
Kingdom: Fungi / Phylum: Basidiomycota / Class: Agaricomycotina / Order: Thelephorales / Family: Thelephoraceae

title: Hydnellum peckii
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description: (size, shape, color, texture)
The Fruiting body has a cap decurrently attaching to its stipe. The hymenium is toothed rather than gilled or pored. The majority of the fruiting body is a cream color, that when moist, exude a thick red fluid in droplets, which give it the appearance of bleeding. Often, the fruiting bodies will grow closely together (1).
Cap / Pileus Characteristics:
The cap is convexed to flat, and is typically uneven, and sometimes depressed in the center. Initially the cap is a cream color but will become a slight brown-red color as it ages. It is covered densely by small hairs that give the fruiting body a velvety texture, but as it ages, the hairs will shed to make the texture smooth (1). 
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.:
The underside of the cap is covered in teeth that make up the hymenium, and the stipe is as well. The teeth on the stipe have a pink tinge to the cream color of the cap, which fades to a grayish brown as the fruiting body matures. The stipe is short and thick, and often deformed. Where the stem meets the ground, it takes on a bulbous shape (1). 
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base:
The stem is thick, very short, and often deformed. It becomes bulbous where it penetrates the ground, and may root into the soil for several centimeters.
Spore Print Color:
Brown
Microscopic Features (if available): (spore size & shape, cystidia, etc.)
Spores generally spherical but with one more pointed end and covered in small nodules. They are about 5 by 4 μm.
Other Diagnostic Characters: (odor, bruising reactions, latex, color change, etc.)
In original species description, odor described as similar to hickory nuts. Cap is dark brown to black when bruised.
Similar Species / Potential Confusions:
Hydnellum scrobiculatum (2)
Hydnellum diabolus (1)

title: Hydnellum peckii
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions):
North America, Europe, recently discovered in Iran and Korea.
Geographic Distribution in WA:
In iNaturalist, documented in the Puget Sound trough, coast, Cascade and Olympic mountains as well as a north east Washington.
Elevation Range:
Found in the lowlands of moist areas of western Washington but has a preference for montane forests.
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: (forest type, soil, leaf litter, dead wood, etc.)
Prefers to grow solitary, scattered, or clustered, under conifers in boreal forests, that are mountainous or subalpine (1). Namely Sitka spruce, Douglas-fir, western hemlock, and many pine species (2). They tend to grow in the duff, the layer of organic matter that is partially to fully decomposed (2). However they have also been found among mosses (1).
Host Associations (if applicable):
H. peckii associates with conifer species within its ranges (1). In the Puget Sound area it is associated with Douglas-fir, hemlocks, true firs, and lodgepole pine along the Oregon coast. It forms ectomycorrhizal relationships with these trees.

title: Hydnellum peckii
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA: June through November
Seasonal Notes: The peak fruiting month is October and the lowest months are December through May. Observations increase from June through October. This pattern seems partially influenced by moisture but also other factors.

title: Hydnellum peckii
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function: (saprotroph, mycorrhizal, parasite, etc.)
Ectomycorrhizal, in fact one of the few species in its family, Bankeraceae whose ectomycorrhizal structure has been studied in detail. Its structure is characterized by a plectenchymatous mantle, a layer of tightly wrapped parallel hyphae. 
Substrate / Decomposition Role:
Often found in pine needles and moss litter.
Interactions: (plants, animals, other fungi, pathogens)
Associated with Doug fir, true firs, hemlock, lodgepole pine on the Oregon Coast, and jack pine in late stage boreal forests.
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators:
A decline has been observed in central Europe which may be due to nitrogen pollution. Since it is an indicator of late stage boreal forests, it only appears when the canopy has closed. For this reason it is impacted by deforesting.

title: Hydnellum peckii
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA:
Only 4116 total observations exist on iNaturalist which is low relative to Hydnellum peckiii’s wide range. Only 19 collections exist in the Burke Herbarium.
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list):
Listed as secure in Canada, including BC (1). Listed as not a concern in Washington on the Burke Herbarium image gallery (6).
Threats / Pressures:
Deforestation and nitrogen pollution
Management or Monitoring Notes:
Not much evidence of active monitoring online. More of the management is happening in Europe through pine forest conservation and pollution management.

title: Hydnellum peckii
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity:
Not poisonous but apparently not pleasant to eat with a persisting pungent smell even when dried.
Traditional / Cultural Uses:
Can be used to make a beige dye.
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds:
Contains atromentin which has anti bacterial and anti coagulant properties as well as thelephoric acid may be used for Alzheimer’s.
Cautions / Warnings:
Not toxic

title: Hydnellum peckii
text:
8. References / Further Reading

Key Literature Sources:
Banker, H. J. (1912). Type Studies in the Hydnaceae: I. The Genus Manina. Mycologia, 4(5), 271–278. https://doi.org/10.2307/3753450
Field Guides / Online Resources:

2.) Hydnellum peckii. (2025). Retrieved from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydnellum_peckii
3.) Red-Juice Tooth (Hydnellum peckii). (n.d.). Retrieved from https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/154949-Hydnellum-peckii
4.) Stevens, M. W. & F. (n.d.). California fungi: Hydnellum peckii. Retrieved from https://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Hydnellum_peckii.html
5.) Weird & wonderful creatures: Bleeding tooth fungus. (2016). Retrieved from https://www.aaas.org/news/weird-wonderful-creatures-bleeding-tooth-fungus
Herbarium / Specimen Records (if applicable):

title: Hydnellum peckii
text:
10. Other Notes & Observations

Field Notes / Observations:
The red droplets on the fruiting body are the result of guttation, a phenomenon when liquid exudes from a plant or fungi.
Questions / Uncertainties:
Do these red droplets serve any reproductive function?
Fun facts
The recognizable oozing red droplets where this species gets its name are actually only present in young fruiting bodies. Once it is done growing it takes on a more nondescript, brown appearance.

title: Morchella exuberans
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Morchella exuberans
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Morchella exuberans
Synonyms / Former Names: Morchella capitata
Common Name(s): Morel
Taxonomic Authority / Citation: Clowez 2012
Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family): Fungi / Ascomycota / Pezizomycetes / Pezizales / Morchellaceae

title: Morchella exuberans
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description: around 5 cm tall, conical cap, brown cap and cream colored stalk, ridges on cap
Cap / Pileus Characteristics: Conical shape with brown color. Mature specimens are dark brown-black. Younger specimens are brown-to-tan. Full of ridges and pits (honeycomb appearance). Pits are elongated vertically. Attached to the stipe via a shallow sinus. Because of the burn-site substrate and charred environment, specimens may carry fire residue on the surface.
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.: Hollow underside.
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base: Hollow like the cap, but one of the diagnostic features of M. exuberance is that the stem is often chambered or layered, especially near the base. Key distinguishing trait. Surface may show shallow longitudinal grooves or fluting, especially near the base. Stipe is typically white to pale colored, especially toward the top; near the base it may become slightly darker or show brownish or ashy discoloration from its substrate. Somewhat firm, the presence of internal chambering may make the stipe appear somewhat segmented when layered or cut vertically.
Spore Print Color: Generally, true morels produce a cream to pale yellow spore deposit.
Microscopic Features (if available): (spore size & shape, cystidia, etc.) Morphologically plastic, many Morchella species look similar. One key diagnostic trait are the capitate acroparaphyses on the sterile ridges of the cap have club-shaped tips. The spores are ellipsoid, hyaline, and smooth/faintly ornamented. They have 8-spored asci typical of ascomycetes. They have septate hyphae.
Other Diagnostic Characters: (odor, bruising reactions, latex, color change, etc.) Burn site habitat is a strong ecological clue. Cap ridges darkening with pits that are elongated vertically, brown to tan. Cap attached to stipe by a shallow sinus. tipe often showing chambered or layered internal structure. A key microscopic clue are capitate acroparaphyses on sterile ridges.
Similar Species / Potential Confusions: Morchella eximia – uniformly hollow, walls thinner Morchella sextelata – hollow, but stipe tends to be longer and more fragile Morchella tomentosa – Thick stipe tissue, not evenly hollow, often cotton-like when young Morchella importuna – hollow, but fruit in mulch, not burns.

title: Morchella exuberans
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions): Western North America is the core range for post-fire fruiting.
Geographic Distribution in WA: Encountered in the first spring (sometimes second) after wildfires, especially in conifer burn sites east of the cascades. This pattern is consistent with western North American post-fire black morels.
Elevation Range: Reported in montane conifer forests, including high-elevation zones in the season after fire.
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: (forest type, soil, leaf litter, dead wood, etc.)
Recently burned conifer forests (especially Douglas fir, true firs, spruce, pine systems) with moderate burn severity bands often proving most productive. These patterns are robust across PNW studies and align with species-level treatments that restrict M. exuberans to conifer burn sites. Fruiting typically peaks during the first post-fire spring, sometimes persisting into a second spring depending on the moisture and temperature as well as the landscape or severity of the burn.
Host Associations (if applicable): Prophilous and conifer-associated at fruiting.


# 1. Get records by taxon_id (Morchella exuberans = 735321)
mexuberans_data <- get_inat_obs(taxon_id = 735321, maxresults = 10000)

# 2. Convert to sf object
mexuberans_sf <- mexuberans_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(latitude), !is.na(longitude)) %>%
  st_as_sf(coords = c("longitude", "latitude"), crs = 4326)

# 3. Get WA state polygon
wa_state <- ne_states(country = "United States of America", returnclass = "sf") %>%
  filter(name == "Washington") %>%
  st_transform(st_crs(mexuberans_sf))

# 4. Keep points inside WA
mexuberans_wa <- mexuberans_sf[st_within(mexuberans_sf, wa_state, sparse = FALSE), ]

# 5. Plot
ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = wa_state, fill = "gray95", color = "black") +
  geom_sf(data = mexuberans_wa, color = "purple", alpha = 0.6, size = 2) +
  labs(
    title = "iNaturalist Observations of Morchella exuberans in Washington State",
    caption = "Data source: iNaturalist"
  ) +
  theme_classic()

title: Morchella exuberans
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA: Spring
Seasonal Notes: Fire dependent. Usually found first or second spring following a fire. They are a pheonicoid fungi meaning they fruits in response to heat. Too much heat will burn the mycelium, but too little heat will not trigger the fungi to fruit.











There were no sightings outside of these three months from iNaturalist.

title: Morchella exuberans
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function: Saprotrophic, occasionally mycorrhizal (mutualistic).
Substrate / Decomposition Role: Prefer slightly acidic pH in soil. Decaying matter that has been burned.
Interactions: Plays a large role in nutrient cycling following fires.
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators: Fire and high heat causes them to form fruiting bodies. They could remain dormant in soil for over 50 years before fire causes them to bloom.

title: Morchella exuberans
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA: They are very abundant in Eastern Washington following fires. Their relationship to fire is very predictable and consistent.
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list): Morchella exuberans is not classified as endangered or threatened.
Threats / Pressures: Fire suppression could potentially limit productivity of Morchella exuberans.
Management or Monitoring Notes: They are heavily foraged which should be considered in management.

title: Morchella exuberans
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity: Edible after proper cooking.
Traditional / Cultural Uses: Used in traditional medicine for treating asthma, indigestion, and excessive phlegm. Morchella exuberans is considered a delicacy in many cultures.
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds: It is intended for cultivation purposes and is not meant to treat/cure diseases.
Cautions / Warnings: Non-true morels are hard to distinguish and can contain monomethyl hydrazine (MMH) which is highly toxic. Be sure to cook properly before consuming.

title: Morchella exuberans
text:
8. References / Further Reading

Key Literature Sources:
DOI: 10.1080/00275514.2017.1408294
Field Guides / Online Resources: https://modern-forager.com/all-about-burn-morels/ https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/735321-Morchella-exuberans
Herbarium / Specimen Records (if applicable): NA

text:

Fruiting Body Photos:

Description: Underside of Morels; Photo credit: Ron Pastorino from Mushroom Observer

Habitat Photo:
![](

title: Morchella exuberans
text:
10. Other Notes & Observations

Field Notes / Observations: Very similar looking to other morels. Can be mistaken with toxic non-true morells.
Questions / Uncertainties: Questions about whether or not they are saprotrophic or just mycorrhizal.
Fun facts: Often referred to as a green/pickle morel!

title: Entomophthora muscae
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Entomophthora muscae
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Entomophthora muscae

Synonyms / Former Names: E. schizophorae, Empusa muscae

Common Name(s): Fly death fungus

Taxonomic Authority / Citation: (Cohn) Fresenius - Mycobank

Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family): Fungi / Zoopagomycota / Entomophthoromycetes/ Entomophthorales / Entomophthoraceae

title: Entomophthora muscae
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description: (size, shape, color, texture) White-clear spores covering the abdomen of infected host. Individually the spores on the conidiophores are very small, but clumped together on the insect they are visible. The conidiophores burst out of the insect, and the conidia (spores) form at the end, forming a thick layer on the host.
Cap / Pileus Characteristics: There is no cap.
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.: There are none of these.
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base: Not applicable.
Spore Print Color: In a non-traditional sense, it is white. If an insect infected with Entomophthora muscae dies on glass, it will leave a white ring of spores around it.
Microscopic Features (if available): (spore size & shape, cystidia, etc.) The spores are white and circular with thick walls for winter survival.
Other Diagnostic Characters: (odor, bruising reactions, latex, color change, etc.) The dead insect will climb to a high point and strike a “death-pose,” where it will lock onto a high point and spread its wings, before dying, making it so the spores can be released easily and effectively.
Similar Species / Potential Confusions: Entomophthora syrphi, which is pretty similar but with far less data, seems to infect the underside of specific insects.

title: Entomophthora muscae
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions): Entomophthora muscae is spread realativly worldwide, whith its largest areas being the east coast of the United States, and Europe.
Geographic Distribution in WA: Entomophthora muscae is found mostly found in the Sound area, with some spottings further north.
Elevation Range: It is found in temperate regions.
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: (forest type, soil, leaf litter, dead wood, etc.) It is found where their host flies are found which is usually damp and cool substrates.
Host Associations (if applicable): Hosts are several families of flies (Diptera).

title: Entomophthora muscae
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA: Usually fruits in Autumn and Spring and sporulation coincides with cool humid conditions in areas with lots of hosts (Diptera).
Seasonal Notes: (peak times, moisture dependence, etc.) As mentioned above, Entomophthora muscae can only persist in cool areas, so its peaks will be Autumn and Spring, with a preference for termperate regions and moist areas (these are also what the host Diptera prefers.)

title: Entomophthora muscae
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function: (saprotroph, mycorrhizal, parasite, etc.) Entomophthora muscae parasite that infects Diptera.
Substrate / Decomposition Role: It kills its host, which in a way leads to decompostion of the insect.
Interactions: (plants, animals, other fungi, pathogens) Infects and kills Diptera flies.
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators: The fungus is temperature sensitive, and cannot survive high temperatures, so it’s present primarily in temperate months. An indicator that the fungus might be present is large groups of the host flies, dead and alive.

title: Entomophthora muscae
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA: Entomophthora muscae are not entirely uncommon in WA, but its range has not been assessed in detail. There are many sightings of this fungus around the Sound, which makes sense due to the environmental needs of the fungus being moist and cool. There are a few other sightings south and east of the Sound, but none in eastern WA, as it is too hot and dry there.
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list): The conservation status of E. muscae in North America has not been assessed, and it is listed as unranked due to lack of data.
Threats / Pressures: The main pressures of Entomophthora muscae are environmental, as it has no known predators. Therefore, the weather and tempature is what will effect it most, as it needs cool and moist environments to thrive.
Management or Monitoring Notes: The only way to monitor the fungus is by monitoring the flies, and there is no current management for killing the fungus, but flies have been known to seak heat to slow the fungus growth.

title: Entomophthora muscae
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity: Not edible, but also not fatal or a concern for humans.
Traditional / Cultural Uses: Potential for use in biological control for constraining pest populations, but difficult to culture because it must be maintained through direct transfer between hosts.
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds: There are no effects for humans, but in its host, the fungus releases toxins called sesquiterpenes, that entice males to mate with an infected female.
Cautions / Warnings: Once again, Entomophthora muscae poses no threat to humans. There could be deleterious ecosystem effects if an outbreak were to reach levels that would cause serious decline in fly populations.

title: Entomophthora muscae
text:
8. References / Further Reading

Key Literature Sources: Dara, Surendra K. and Humber, Richard A. “Chapter 39 - Entomophthoran.” Beneficial Microbes in Agro-Ecology, edited by N. Amaresan, M. Senthil Kumar, K. Annapurna, Krishna Kumar, and A. Sankaranarayanan, Academic Press, 2020, pp. 757-775. doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-12-823414-3.00039-3.
Naundrup, Andreas et al. “Pathogenic fungus uses volatiles to entice male flies into fatal matings with infected female cadavers.” The ISME Journal, vol. 16, no. 10, 2022, pp. 2388-2397. doi:10.1038/s41396-022-01284-x.  
Field Guides / Online Resources: “Entomophthora muscae.” iNaturalist, www.inaturalist.org/taxa/1098570-Entomophthora-muscae#articles-tab. “Entomophthora muscae.” NatureServe Explorer, 3 Oct. 2025, explorer.natureserve.org/Taxon/ELEMENT_GLOBAL.2.1086383/Entomophthora_muscae. Watson, D.W. “Entomophthora muscae.” Biological Control: A Guide to Natural Enemies in North America. Cornell University College of Agriculture and Life Sciences. biocontrol.entomology.cornell.edu/pathogens/entomophagamuscae.php. Volk, Thomas J. “Tom Volk’s Fungus of the Month for March 2000.” Tom Volk Fungi, botit.botany.wisc.edu/toms_fungi/mar2000.html.  
Herbarium / Specimen Records (if applicable):N/A

Fun facts: Infected flies have been known to go near heat sources to raise their temperature and stop fungal growth Entomo- means insect, -phthora means destroyer, musca = house fly genus, latin for fly

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
Synonyms / Former Names: Obligate Synonyms: Podisoma juniperi-virginianae; Tremella juniperi-virginianae; Taxonomic Synonyms: Gymnosporangium virginianum; Aecidium juniperi-virginianae; Gymnosporangium/Podisoma macropus; Roestelia/Aecidium/Caeoma pyrata/pyratum/piratum
Common Names: Cedar-apple Rust; Juniper-apple Rust; Cedar Rust
Taxonomic Authority / Citation: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae Schweinitz, Schriften Naturf. Ges. Leipzig (1822)
Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family): Kingdom Fungi / Phylum Basidiomycota / Subphylum Pucciniomycotina / Class Pucciniomycetes / Order Rust Fungi / Suborder Uredinineae / Family Gymnosporangiaceae / Genus Cedar Rusts (Gymnosporangium)

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description:
Telial Stage: 6-50mm reddish-brown round galls hydrate to produce 10-20mm long bright orange gelatinous telia horns that produce teliospores, that when germinated, produce basidia that release basidiospores to be carried to apple leaves by the wind.
Aecial Stage: yellow-orange to orange-red pycnia flask-like lesions on upper apple leaf surfaces that produce pycniospores and a sticky substance to attract insects which transport pycniospores between lesions. Tube-like orange-yellow aecia form on the on undersurface of leaves, and produce aeciospores to be carried to cedar trees by the wind.
Cap / Pileus Characteristics: N/A
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.: Basidia formed at skin of telia horns
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base: Galls begin as small bumps on the woody portion of the plant such as needle bases or through cracks of branches.
Spore Print Color: White/cream spores, unobtainable print
Microscopic Features: two-celled teliospores; basidiospores, pycniospores, aeciospores
Other Diagnostic Characters: Telial Stage: cycles between orange gelatinous cones (wet) and dark brown threads (dry) 8-10 times during the spring
Similar Species / Potential Confusions: Gymnotelium blasdaleanum and Puccinia coronata; other Gymnosporangiums: G. clavariiforme, G. clavipes, G. corniculans, G. cornutum

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions): North America, including Central Eastern US & Canada, anywhere with overlap of Junipers and Crab/Apple trees
Geographic Distribution in WA: mostly Puget Sound Region and Islands; borders near with Idaho
Elevation Range: 150-1500m
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: Apple tree leaves and Juniper leaves and branches
Host Associations: Telial Host: Eastern Red Cedar (Juniperus virginiana) (and other Juniper spp.); Aecial Host: Rosaceous family commonly including apples and crab apples (Malus), as well as hawthorn (Crataegus) or serviceberry (Amelanchier)

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA: April-June
Seasonal Notes: Telial fruiting in spring with rainfall and stops when dry and warm. Aecial development throughout Summer and Autumn, pycniospores go dormant for winter up to 2 years, gall formation slowly develops until spring.

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function: non-lethal plant pathogen, reduces host fruiting quality and yield
Substrate / Decomposition Role: Apple tree leaves and Juniper leaves and branches
Interactions: Host specific to Junipers (Juniperus) and Roses (Rosaceae); sporulation assisted by insects and wind
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators: N/A

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA: Uncommon, compared to East Coast region
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list): N/A, not assessed
Threats / Pressures: Forest fires, deforestation
Management or Monitoring Notes: Preventive fungicides and select pruning; apple orchard transportation regulations

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity: Not edible, undesirable; unstudied
Traditional / Cultural Uses: Not useful; indigenous practices of controlled burns to regulate spread
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds: phenolic acids (anthocyanins, purpurogallin, flavonoids, tannins, steroids, tritepenes, alkaloids, lipophillic components
Cautions / Warnings: None

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text:
9. Images / Illustrations

Fruiting Body Photos:



Shrivelled brown horns on gall during telial stage before rain (April 2008); Photo credit: Botond Balogh




Gelantinous orange horns on gall during telial stage after rain (April 2008); Photo credit: Len Burgess




Early aecial infection of pycnia lesions on underside of leaf. Photo credit: Daria McKelvey

Habitat Photo:



Red Cedar with heavy infestation of teliohorns (early-May 2012). Photo credit: David D. Taylor

Microscopy Photo:



Two-celled teliospore under microscope (April 2008). Photo credit: Botond Balogh

title: Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
text:
10. Other Notes & Observations

Questions / Uncertainties: Not extensively studied
Fun facts: Rust life cycles are cool! Also it only has four of the five rust spore types. Gymno=naked, sporangium=fruit body, hence the orange slick bodies! Different spp of the same genus develop various types of orange “horns,” such as club-horns, cones, and finger-like appendages.

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Rhizopogon vinicolor
Synonyms / Former Names: NA
Common Name(s): Wine-colored Pogie
Taxonomic Authority / Citation: Mycobank
Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family):
Fungi -> Dikarya -> Basidiomycota -> Agaricomycotina -> Agaricomycetes -> Agaricomycetidae -> Boletales -> Rhizopogonaceae -> Rhizopogon -> Rhizopogon Vinicolor

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description:

Size: 10 to 33 mm in diameter
Shape: rounded or irregularly shaped
Color: dusty white color and later red
Texture: few rhizomorphs at the base

Cap / Pileus Characteristics:
Single layer, becomes wine red when exposed.
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.:
Filled with basidiospores.
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base:
Base with few rhizomorphs.
Spore Print Color:
NA
Microscopic Features (if available): (spore size & shape, cystidia, etc.)

Trama filled with basidiospores
Basidiospores elliptical to ovid
5-9 x 3-5 um in size
Do not have a septum, smooth, and hyaline
Mycelial cords are few in number of absent altogether

Other Diagnostic Characters:

Odor: slightly fruity
Bruising reactions: becomes vinaceous when exposed or bruised
Color change: peridium becomes wine red when exposed. The body starts as a dirty color with tinges of yellow and staining pink, then becomes wine red.
Texture: rubbery

Similar Species / Potential Confusions:

Rhizopogon vesiculosus, and some species of Amanita (early in their life cycles)

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions):
Clatlam, Snohomish, Kitsap, Pierce, Thurston, Lewis, Cowlitz, Clark, Skamania, Klickitat, Kittilas, Pend Oreille
Geographic Distribution in WA:
Western Coastal Washington and Central Cascades
Elevation Range:
Wide elevation range: sea level to 610m (Western Washington) and up to 1520 m (Central Cascades)
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: (forest type, soil, leaf litter, dead wood, etc.)
Old growth Douglas fir stands, soil, roots
Host Associations (if applicable):
Douglas fir

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA:
The primary fruiting period is in the spring from February to July, but they can be found year round.
Seasonal Notes: (peak times, moisture dependence, etc.)
Fruiting season is triggered by rain. The best time to look is in the weeks after significant rain has saturated the forest floor. The fungus itself is drought-resistant and can help the host trees survive dry spells.

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function:
Ectomycorrhizal relationship with Douglas fir, saprotroph.
Substrate / Decomposition Role:
Saprotrophyic.
Interactions:
They have a mutualistic relationship with Douglas firs. They breakdown leaf litter and rotting wood for nutrient availability for the Douglas Firs in exchange for carbohydrates.
Western red-backed vole feeds on their fruiting bodies, the spores pass through their guts, and are deposited in fecal pellets. These spores remain viable and form associations with uninfected trees. 
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators:
If a forest is clear-cut and the dead wood is removed, Rhizopogon vinicolor stops fruiting, the vole population dies out, and newly planted trees fail to thrive. Tree growth is positively associated with the presence of R. vinicolor.

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA:
Highly abundant in Douglas fir stands in Washington. 
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list):
Not of concern
Threats / Pressures:
Clear-cutting of old-growth Douglas fir stands
Management or Monitoring Notes:
Preserve old-growth Douglas firs to maintain the relationship and presence between Douglas firs, voles, and R. vinicolor.

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity:
It is edible, but due to its small size, rubbery/foam-like texture, and mild flavor, some say it requires more effort in the kitchen than the results justify.
Traditional / Cultural Uses:
No known traditional or cultural uses.
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds:
It has the ability to inhibit the growth of certain root pathogens like Phytophthora cinnamomi and Pythium debaryanum. 
Cautions / Warnings:
Advised not to eat unless you are 100% sure of the identity, as some species of Amanita, which are highly toxic and begin life in an egg-shaped sac, may look similar.

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
8. References / Further Reading

Key Literature Sources: 
KRETZER, ANNETTE M., et al. “Patterns of vegetative growth and gene flow in rhizopogon vinicolor and R. vesiculosus (Boletales, Basidiomycota).” Molecular Ecology, vol. 14, no. 8, 11 May 2005, pp. 2259–2268, https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-294x.2005.02547.x. 
Luoma DL, Frenkel RE, Trappe JM. Fruiting of hypogeous fungi in Oregon Douglas-fir forests: Seasonal and habitat variation. Mycologia. 1991;83(3):335-353. doi:10.1080/00275514.1991.12026018
Zak, B. “Characterization and classification of mycorrhizae of Douglas fir. II. pseudotsuga menziesii + rhizopogon vinicolor.” Canadian Journal of Botany, vol. 49, no. 7, 1 July 1971, pp. 1079–1084, https://doi.org/10.1139/b71-154. 
Field Guides / Online Resources:
Trappe, James, and Matt Trappe. “Specific Habitats: Seasonality and Habitat Associations of Some PNW Truffles.” Fruiting Patterns and Habitat Associations of PNW Truffles, 2007, www.natruffling.org/blurbs.htm#:~:text=Name:%20Cystangium%20vesiculosum,middle%20elevations%20in%20the%20mountains. 
“Wine-Colored Pogie (Rhizopogon Vinicolor).” iNaturalist, 13 Jan. 2024, www.inaturalist.org/taxa/384122-Rhizopogon-vinicolor#articles-tab. 
Herbarium / Specimen Records:
WTU Herbarium, Burke Museum. “Rhizopogon Vinicolor.” Rhizopogon Vinicolor - Burke Herbarium Image Collection, University of Washington, burkeherbarium.org/imagecollection/taxon.php?Taxon=Rhizopogon+vinicolor. Accessed 23 Oct. 2025.

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
9. Images / Illustrations

Fruiting Body Photos:



Description; Photo credit: Photographer Name




Description; Photo credit: Photographer Name

Habitat Photo:



Description; Photo credit: Photographer Name

Microscopy Photo (if available):



Description, Photo credit: Photographer Name

title: Rhizopogon vinicolor
text:
10. Other Notes & Observations

Field Notes / Observations: Some have observed its existence around pines and other firs besides the Doug fir.
Questions / Uncertainties:

Uncertain about the elevation range 
No cultural importance was written about, but it could exist, just not in the literature. 

Fun facts

R. vinicolor can grow under significant water stress and remains active under drought conditions. This leads to increased establishment and survival rate of inoculated tree seedlings on harsh, dry sites. 
R. vinicolor can enhance the net photosynthesis of Douglas-fir seedlings. 
R. vinicolor is a valuable model organism for studying the population genetics of ectomycorrhizal fungi due to its clear association with Douglas-fir and its distinct genetic markers.

title: Beauveria bassiana
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Beauveria bassiana
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Beauveria bassiana
Synonyms / Former Names: Botrytis bassiana
Common Name(s): White muscardine fungus or Icing Sugar Fungus
Taxonomic Authority / Citation: (Bassi 1835)












Scientific Classification



Rank
Name




Kingdom
Fungi


Phylum
Ascomycota


Class
Ascomycetes


Order
Hypocreales


Family
Cordycipitaceae


Genus
Beauveria

title: Beauveria bassiana
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description: White, fluffy mold that grows on a host (size, shape, color, texture)
Cap / Pileus Characteristics: This fungi does not have a cap
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.: This fungi does not have gills, pores, spines, or teeth
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base: This fungi does not have a fruiting body with any of these morphological features
Spore Print Color: White or yellowish white
Microscopic Features (if available): Produces white spore balls made of single-celled conidia. Has conidiogenous cells that are short, ovoid, and have a rachis; septate hyphae.
Other Diagnostic Characters: This fungi is powdery while sporulating.
Similar Species / Potential Confusions: Can be confused with Metarhizium and Akanthomyces species as well as other Beauveria species

title: Beauveria bassiana
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions): Distributed worldwide, generally seems to be more abundant on coasts and islands. Found from Everett down to Chehalis
Geographic Distribution in WA: Distributed mostly along the Western side of Washington
Elevation Range: Mainly found at low to mid elevations, seems to be found in forested areas
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: Occurs in soil, prefers humid, temperate climates
Host Associations (if applicable): often seen on insects (ants, beetles, moths, worms, bees), has been observed on reptiles

title: Beauveria bassiana
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA: Has been most observed from June to October
Seasonal Notes: Peaks in warm, moist weather during these months

title: Beauveria bassiana
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function: Saprotroph and/or parasite
Substrate / Decomposition Role: lives in soil, finds insect as a host, takes over insect body, and eventually decomposes it
Interactions: Interacts with insects
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators: As the weather gets warmer due to climate change, this fungi will likely become more abundant

title: Beauveria bassiana
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA: Seems to be moderately abundant in WA
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list): Does not have a global conservation status, is listed as vulnerable in Alberta and Manitoba, CA
Threats / Pressures: Climate change, fungi does well in warm, moist environments
Management or Monitoring Notes: Does not seem to be managed or monitored at this time, not seen as a threat

title: Beauveria bassiana
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity: Not edible, spores may worsen breathing difficulties, at least one case of human infection has been reported in a person with a suppressed immune system
Traditional / Cultural Uses: Commonly used for pest control
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds: This fungus is a contact mycoinsecticide that is registered for use in the US on pests and agricultural and horticultural crops
Cautions / Warnings: Can be harmful to humans if ingested and can cause eye irritation. Could harm pollinators and other beneficial insects as well as fish.

title: Beauveria bassiana
text:
8. References / Further Reading

Key Literature Sources:
Field Guides / Online Resources: https://cals.cornell.edu/integrated-pest-management/outreach-education/fact-sheets/beauveria-bassiana https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beauveria_bassiana https://explorer.natureserve.org/Taxon/ELEMENT_GLOBAL.2.1072881/Beauveria_bassiana https://www.gbif.org/occurrence/charts?has_coordinate=true&has_geospatial_issue=false&taxon_key=2560612&geometry=POLYGON((-124.72585%2043.56442,-113.47585%2043.56442,-113.47585%2051.44445,-118.65434%2051.44445,-124.72585%2051.44445,-124.72585%2043.56442))&occurrence_status=present https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/862160-Beauveria-bassiana#status-tab
Herbarium / Specimen Records (if applicable):

text:
9. Images / Illustrations

Fruiting Body Photos:


Description; Photo credit: Photographer Name




Description; Photo credit: Photographer Name

Habitat Photo:



Description; Photo credit: Photographer Name

Microscopy Photo (if available):



Description, Photo credit: Photographer Name

title: Beauveria bassiana
text:
10. Other Notes & Observations

Field Notes / Observations: Looking at iNaturalist observations most recorded findings of this fungi in Washington state have been in natural areas or forests and have been seen mainly on insects.
Questions / Uncertainties: Will it eventually become harmful to use this fungi as a pesticide?
Fun facts: This fungus is a cordiceps and can kill insects within 4-10 days. It is able to infect 700 different species of insects and can colonize plants to help them resist pests.

title: Laccaria bicolor
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Laccaria bicolor
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current):
Laccaria bicolor (Maire) P.D. Orton, Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc. 43 (2): 177 (1960) [MB#332790] 
Synonyms / Former Names:
Laccaria proxima var. bicolor (Maire) Kühner & Romagn., Flore Analytique des Champignons Supérieurs: 131 (1953) [MB#456881]
Laccaria laccata var. pseudobicolor Bon, Doc. Mycol. 12 (46): 42 (1982) [MB#117108] 
Laccaria bicolor var. pseudobicolor (Bon) Pázmány, Not. Bot. Horti Agrobot. Cluj-Napoca 20-21: 14 (1991) [MB#361379] 
Common Name(s):
Deceiver (Money NP), Bicolored Deceiver
Taxonomic Authority / Citation:
Laccaria bicolor (Maire) P.D. Orton, Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc. 43 (2): 177 (1960) [MB#332790] 
Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family):
Fungi > Dikarya > Basidiomycota > Agaricomycotina > Agaricomycetes > Agaricomycetidae > Agaricales > Agaricineae > Hydnangiaceae > Laccaria > Laccaria bicolor

title: Laccaria bicolor
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description: (size, shape, color, texture)
Orange-brown in color, hygrophanous surface that becomes more translucent with moisture. Texture is hairy/scaly. Cap is typically 10-70mm across and stipe is typically 30-100mm long.
Cap / Pileus Characteristics:
Has a broad and convex pileus sometimes with a depression in the center, 10-70mm across. Margins often curl inward and under toward the stipe.
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.:
Gills adnate, occasionally notched. Light purple/lilac in color but fade with age. Gills are fairly thick and broad, around 5-8mm, and have even edges.
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base:
Same orange-brown color as the cap, hollow and without a veil. 30-100mm long and 10mm thick. Lilac mycelium at base, which is slightly swollen.
Spore Print Color:
White
Microscopic Features (if available): (spore size & shape, cystidia, etc.)
7-9 x 6-8 microns in size, elliptical to round with small spines around 1-2 microns long. Nonamyloid with four-spores basidia. Has filamentous cheilocystidia.
Other Diagnostic Characters: (odor, bruising reactions, latex, color change, etc.)
Color change due to moisture gain/loss can make it difficult to discern between similar species. Odor and taste not distinctive.
Similar Species / Potential Confusions:
Laccaria proxima, L. laccata, L. amethysteo-occidentalis, L. noblis, L. fraterna

title: Laccaria bicolor
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions):
Common across North American coastal regions. Western North America, the Great Lakes, and West Virginia. Debatable whether similar individuals in Northern Europe are of the same species.
Geographic Distribution in WA:
On the west side of Cascade, mainly distributed in Western Washington.
Elevation Range:
Mainly found in temperate and boreal forests.
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: (forest type, soil, leaf litter, dead wood, etc.)
Conifer/boreal forests, often found in moss.
Host Associations (if applicable):
Ectomycorrhizal with pine/birch host roots

title: Laccaria bicolor
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA:
Summer and Fall, peak in October
Seasonal Notes: (peak times, moisture dependence, etc.)
Peak time in October, prefers high moisture boreal/temperate forests and is often found in/around moss.

title: Laccaria bicolor
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function: (saprotroph, mycorrhizal, parasite, etc.)
Mycorrhizal with conifers, carnivorous. Saprotrophic and biotrophic, as demonstrated by Martin et al. (2008).
Substrate / Decomposition Role:
Cannot degrade plant cell walls, but can degrade other polysaccharides, according to Martin et al. (2008).
Interactions: (plants, animals, other fungi, pathogens)
Carnivorous and consumes insects such as springtails (Folsomia candida) in order to provide nitrogen to the conifers (such as Pinus strobus) it has ectomycorrhizal associations with. It receives carbon from the trees in exchange.
It produces a toxin in order to immobilize the insects prior to hyphae invasion. In an experiment done by Klironomos & Hart (2001], 15N-labeled springtails were placed in the presence of only the fungus, not the plant roots, but the fungus was in contact with the Pinus seedlings via mycorrhizal association. After two months, they found 15N in the plant foliage and determined that up to 25% of the Pinus nitrogen came from the springtails, which they had no connection with other than through Laccaria bicolor. Less than 10% of the springtails remained by the end of the experiment. 
As demonstrated by Schrey et al. (2012), some streptomycete bacteria are able to induce and support the growth of Laccaria bicolor.
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators:
Laccaria bicolor is sensitive to soil zinc pollution, but ectomycorrhizal associations with hosts are maintained in the presence of this pollution, as shown by Ottoway et al. (2025).

title: Laccaria bicolor
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA:
Native in Washington, not rare.
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list):
Not listed under the Endangered Species Act, not of concern according to the Burke Herbarium. 
Threats / Pressures:
Soil zinc pollution. 
Management or Monitoring [Notes:\\](Notes:){.uri} None. Not of concerned.

title: Laccaria bicolor
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity:
Edible but doesn’t really taste like anything.
Traditional / Cultural Uses:
None.
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds:
Laccaria bicolor produces sesquiterpenes when associated with Populus or Arabadopsis in order to stimulate lateral root growth prior to direct contact, as shown by Ditengou et al. (2015).
Cautions / Warnings:
None.

text:

title: Laccaria bicolor
text:
10. Other Notes & Observations

Field Notes / Observations:
Color change due to moisture gain/loss can make it difficult to discern between similar species. It is also sometimes regarded as a subspecies of Laccaria laccata.
Fun facts: Carnivorous and consumes insects such as springtails (Folsomia candida) in order to provide nitrogen to the conifers (such as Pinus strobus) it has ectomycorrhizal associations with. It receives carbon from the trees in exchange.

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Cortinarius violaceus
Synonyms / Former Names: Agaricus violaceus L., Cortinarius violaceus (L.) Fr., Inoloma violaceum (L. ex Fr.) Wunsche
Common Name(s): Violet cort, Violet webcap, Cap Gweog Fioled (Welsh)
Taxonomic Authority / Citation: (L.) Gray
Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family): Fungi / Basidiomycota / Agaricomycetes / Agaricales / Cortinariaceae

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description: The fruiting body takes the shape of a gilled mushroom that can be 4-10 cm wide and 6-15 cm tall. It has a violet cap and stipe and dark violet, blackish gills. It is generally textured with small hairs and scales.
Cap / Pileus Characteristics: The cap is typically 4-10 cm across and is somewhat velvety, roughened by many hairs and small scales. It tends to crack when dry and is colored a deep blackish violet to deep purple. Unlike many other Cortinarius species, the cap is not slimy.
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.: The gills have an adnate attachment to the stem. They are covered by a cobwebby purple partial veil when young, but this disappears quickly. They begin as dark purple, become grayish to blackish, and end as rusty brown.
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base: The stipe is 6-15 cm long, with a base ranging from bulbous to slightly thickened, and has a partial veil. It is somewhat hairy and is not slimy. Over time, the stem darkens deeply, indicating age.
Spore Print Color: Rusty brown or cinnamon.
Microscopic Features: Spores are 11.5-14.5 x 7-9 µm and are ellipsoid to amygadaliform (almond-shaped), with a moderately verrucose (warty) surface texture. The cheilocystidia (edge of gills) and pleurocystidia (face of gills) are fusoid-ventricose (spindle-shaped, wider in the middle), with a long neck. It is the only Cortinarius species with clearly defined cystidia on its gills.
Other Diagnostic Characters: It is described by various sources as having a cedarwood smell, a sweet fragrance, or no distinct smell. It turns red when it comes into contact with potassium hydroxide (KOH).
Similar Species / Potential Confusions:

Viscid violet cort (Cortinarius iodes)
Gassy webcap (Cortinarius traganus)
Silvery-violet cort (Cortinarius alboviolaceus)
Amethyst deceiver (Laccaria amethystina)
Blewit (Clitocybe nuda)

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions): Temperate areas in the Northern Hemisphere (found in both North America and Europe).
Geographic Distribution in WA: Largely found to the west of the Cascade Mountains (in old-growth forests both inland and on the coast). Also sometimes found in the northeastern corner of the state (Pend Oreille County).
Elevation Range: There is no definitive elevation range for the fungus itself. However, the old-growth forests it favors occur from sea level to around 4,000 feet.
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: In Washington state, it is most often found growing in old-growth conifer forests, but it also grows in mixed woods. It grows on the ground and is often found near rotting logs.
Host Associations: It is more often reported with conifers in North America and deciduous forests of broadleaf trees in Europe.

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA: June through December.
Seasonal Notes: Peaks in October and prefers moist soil.

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function: Forms ectomycorrhizal relationships with hardwoods or conifers.
Substrate / Decomposition Role: It is not known as a saprotrophic mushroom.
Interactions: As an ectomycorrhizal fungus, it enhances nutrient and water uptake for host trees while receiving carbohydrates in return.
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators: Indicates healthy old-growth forests.

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA: Commonly encountered in WA, but in small numbers.
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list): Not of concern.
Threats / Pressures: Currently, there are no specific threats to this species. However, it is assumed that when old-growth forests are impacted, this species will be as well.
Management or Monitoring Notes: Requires conservation of mature forest stands, avoidance of clearcutting and soil compaction, and maintenance of leaf litter, coarse woody debris (CWD), and natural hydrology.

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity: They are considered edible, but not choice, and so are not recommended for consumption. They may taste bitter when cooked.
Traditional / Cultural Uses: There are currently no documented uses for this species for culinary or medicinal uses.
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds: It likely contains some compounds with anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, but more research is needed.
Cautions / Warnings: There are no serious warnings for consumption or use of this species. However, it has some lookalikes within the Cortinarius family that are toxic.

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text:
8. References / Further Reading

Key Literature Sources:

All That the Rain Promises, and More… (David Arora)
Mushrooms Demystified (David Arora)
Mushrooms of Cascadia (Noah Siegel and Christian Schwarz)


Field Guides / Online Resources:

https://www.mushroomexpert.com/cortinarius_violaceus.html
https://species.nbnatlas.org/species/NHMSYS0001479566

https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/124344-Cortinarius-violaceus
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10647524/

title: Cortinarius violaceus
text:
10. Other Notes & Observations

Field Notes / Observations:

I (Kavya) have always found this fungus growing either by itself or in small groups of 3-5.

Questions / Uncertainties:

The description of the smell is somewhat different between sources (cedar wood, vague sweetness, or no distinctive smell).

Fun facts

Its fruiting body contains around 100 times more iron than most other fungal species.

title: Suillus lakei
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Suillus lakei
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Suillus lakei
Synonyms / Former Names: Boletus lakei, Boletinus lakei
Common Name(s): matte Jack, Lake’s bolete, western painted Suillus, Lake’s slippery cap.
Taxonomic Authority / Citation: (Murill) A.H. Sm & Thiers
Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family): Kingdom Fungi, Phylum Basidiomycota, Class Agaricomycetes, Order Boletales, Family Suillaceae

title: Suillus lakei
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description: (size, shape, color, texture)
Cap / Pileus Characteristics: Cap 4-12 cm, broad and convex. Shape changes over time, with the margin incurved when younger and nearly plane with age. Surface color brown with scaly texture, flesh color light yellow, subcuticle yellow.
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.: Pores that change in color over time, aging into a darker brown color. Tubes are adnate or decurrent on hymenium.
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base: 3-7 cm in height, 1.5-2.5 cm thick (Mykoweb, 2021). Veil thin and may leave remnants on the cap, and may form larger veil on the stipe. Stipe yellow at the top, red-brown lower down.
Spore Print Color: Brown
Microscopic Features (if available): spores 7.5-10 by 3-4 µm, subellipsoid and smooth shape (Mykoweb, 2021). (spore size & shape, cystidia, etc.)
Other Diagnostic Characters: Strong odor. Flesh occasionally turns pink when cut. Flesh turns blue when cut at the base. Shape of cap or color of different parts may change over time.
Similar Species / Potential Confusions: S. spraguei, S. cavipes, S. ochraceoroseus, S. ponderosus, S. cauerulescens, S. decipiens.

title: Suillus lakei
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions): Primarily the Rocky Mountains and the Northwest United States/ Southwest Canada.
Geographic Distribution in WA: Eastern and Western Washington, avoiding the inner (hotter, drier) counties. More prevalent along the coast of Washington and up into Vancouver island.
Elevation Range: No clear elevation range. However, can be assumed that it follows Douglas fir elevation ranges - from sea level to 10,700 feet.
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: Prefers poor, exposed soil, such as in campgrounds or road banks (iNaturalist). Will be close to the roots of Douglas fir trees.
Host Associations (if applicable): Forms ectomycorrhizae with Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii).

title: Suillus lakei
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA: Late summer and autumn, potentially even later.
Seasonal Notes: Based on iNaturalist images, fruits the most in October. Rain may alter appearance of cap surface, making it more sticky and slimy. Age may smoothen mushroom from scaly texture over time.

title: Suillus lakei
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function: Mycorrhizal
Substrate / Decomposition Role: Typically on the ground near or under Douglas fir trees; Suillus lakei colonizes root structures to live. This is a mutualistic relationship with these trees.
Interactions: Forms ectomycorrhizae with Douglas fir, and is only present in areas where there are Douglas Fir.
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators: As it associates with Douglas fir trees (Psedotsuga menziesii), a reduction in these species could cause a corresponding reduction in S. lakei populations. Is often found alongside Gomphidius subroseus on or near Douglas firs.

title: Suillus lakei
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA: Indigenous to this area! Fairly common, one of the most common boletes found in nearby states (Montana, Idaho).
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list): No concern in the United States. Listed as endangered in the Czech Republic.
Threats / Pressures: No specific pressures, besides those that would affect Douglas fir, such as root rot, drought, or insect-related diseases. These would only significantly affect Suillus lakei if Douglas fir populations were majorly reduced.
Management or Monitoring Notes: Only reason for endangered status in the Czech Republic is due to the ornamental nature of Douglas fir, leading to little wild opportunity for Suillus lakei to flourish.

title: Suillus lakei
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity: Edible! But not very tasty nor a good texture.
Traditional / Cultural Uses: None listed or described.
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds: Mushrooms have antimicrobial activity and contain alkaloids and tannins (iNaturalist, 2025).
Cautions / Warnings: May taste bad!!

title: Suillus lakei
text:
8. References / Further Reading
Key Literature Sources:

Wood, Michael. “California Fungi-Suillus lakei” Mykoweb, 2021, https://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Suillus_lakei.html
“Western Painted Suillus (Suillus lakei) iNaturalist, iNaturalist Network, 2025, https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/118159-Suillus-lakei#articles-tab
“Suillus lakei (Murill) A.H. Sm. & Thiers” The Global Fungal Red List, 2018, https://redlist.info/iucn/species_view/339853

Field Guides / Online Resources: Mykoweb, iNaturalist

title: Suillus lakei
text:
9. Images / Illustrations

Fruiting Body Photos:



Description: Image of cap of Suillus lakei Photo credit: miahwhiteaker on iNaturalist




Description: Underside and hymenium of Suillus lakei Photo credit: edwardrice on iNaturalist

Habitat Photo:



Description: 2 examples of Suillus lakei in habitat Photo credit: chanterellerin on iNaturalist

Microscopy Photo :



Description: Photo of Suillus lakei basidiospores at 10 μm Photo credit: B. Assyov on boletales.com (boletales.com/genera/suillus/s-lakei/):

title: Suillus lakei
text:
10. Other Notes & Observations

Fun Facts:

If not for the distribution of Douglas fir to new regions, this species would most likely not be present anywhere outside of the Douglas fir’s natural range. The prescence of Suillus lakei in New Zealand is a good example of this phenomena.
The main difference between this species and its lookalikes is the trees that it is present on: tree species designates a species difference. However, all of these other species are edible as well, despite retaining the displeasurable taste and texture.
Was initially named incorrectly, leading to the original discoverers name in parentheses before the names of the researchers who did the modern reassessment to rename it.
In Washington, there are always significant mushroom sighting highs in October, according to iNaturalist. This goes slightly against the Mykoweb description that the Pacific Northwest may have these mushrooms sprouting later in the season, or maybe this distinction has changed since the initial writing of that article.

title: Thelephora terrestris
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Thelephora terrestris
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Thelephora terrestris
Synonyms / Former Names: NA
Common Name(s): Earthfan fungus | Common Fiber Vase | Groundwart
Taxonomic Authority / Citation: Stevens, F, and Wood, M. (2007-2021) “California Fungi-Thelephora terrestris.” The Fungi of California. Retrieved from: https://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Thelephora_terrestris.html. Kuo, M. (2015, December). Thelephora terrestris. Retrieved from the MushroomExpert.Com Web site: http://www.mushroomexpert.com/thelephora_terrestris.html “Common Fiber Vase (Thelephora terrestris).” iNaturalist.org. Retrieved from: https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/118102-Thelephora-terrestris. Jones, Julie. “Thelephora terrestris: earthfan, common fiber vase, groundwart.” Burke Herbarium Image Collection. Retrieved from: https://burkeherbarium.org/imagecollection/taxon.php?Taxon=Thelephora%20terrestris.
Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family): Fungi > Basidiomycota > Agaricomycetes > Thelephorales > Thelephoraceae

title: Thelephora terrestris
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description:
Mostly brown with white cap outline. Young fruiting bodies start off light brown and turn a darker shade as they mature, with the mushroom forming frilly rosettes. Its common name is derived from its fan-like shape. Mushrooms as large as 6 cm wide have been observed (iNaturalist.org).
Cap / Pileus Characteristics:
The cap is fan-shaped, or semi-circular and slightly depressed (iNaturalist.org; burkeherbarium.org; minnesotaseasons.com). The texture has been described as silky, fibrillose, brown fan-shaped caps, with a leathery texture and a white border (mushroomexpert.com). Sometimes the rim of the cap can be “frilly” (ibid).
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.:
Gray to brown, smooth, with small pores (iNaturalist.org; burkeherbarium.org; minnesotaseasons.com; mushroomexpert.com). In old age the underside can become slightly wrinkled, sometimes described as “bumpy” (ibid).
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base:
The stipe is usually very short or not present at all–tends to depend on substrate type. The texture of the stipe is tough and its coloration is similar to the cap, maybe slightly lighter (ibid).
Spore Print Color:
Spore print is brown (mushroomexpert.com).
Microscopic Features (if available):
The basidiospores have a “bumpy” or spiny-looking surface. They are about 7-10 μm across and 5-6 μm tall. Similar to a number of other species within basidiomycota, clamp connections visible on T. terrestris hyphae (ibid).
Other Diagnostic Characters:
Most sites noted that it does not have a distinctive flavor, but has a moldy earth-like smell (iNaturalist.org; burkeherbarium.org; minnesotaseasons.com; mushroomexpert.com).
Similar Species / Potential Confusions:
According to Kuo (mushroomexpert.com), the version of this fungus that grows in North America is probably not the same one that was originally described in Europe in the 18th century! Thelephora palmata is a “stinkier” look-alike of T. terrestris. T. palmata is also more branched and coral-like, and less abundant (iNaturalist.org; burkeherbarium.org; minnesotaseasons.com; mushroomexpert.com). T. vialis is another similar species, but iNat describes it as “more robust.” Cotylidia diaphana and Podoscypha petalodes can look similar as well. Finally, the upper surface of Hydnellum caps resemble those of T. terrestris, but have “teeth” underneath (iNaturalist.org).

title: Thelephora terrestris
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range & Geographic Distribution in WA:
Worldwide, T. terrestris exists in almost every continent, but is notably absent between the latitudes 30ºN and 30ºS (minnesotaseasons.com). In Washington, T. terrestris is more commonly found west of the Cascade Range, around King, Snohomish, Skagit, Whatcom, Pierce, Thurston, Mason, Kitsap County, including some recorded sightings in Clallam, Skamania, Stevens, and Spokane County (iNaturalist.org; burkeherbarium.org). The range seems to stretch up the coast, into British Columbia, and southward into Oregon and California. In these regions, T. terrestris finds tend to follow the pattern in Washington: they are localized to the coast, with sparser observations east of the Cascades (iNaturalist.org).
Elevation Range:
We could not find any information on elevation range.
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences:
T. terrestris is most commonly found in sandy soils, usually close to or underneath host species (iNaturalist.org). However, this species is quite widely distributed and sturdy, so it can establish on a variety of soil types. For instance, it’s commonly seen on roadside ditches, acidic soils, post-wildfire soils and soils with tephra deposits. It also dominates in ecosystems that have been treated with fungicides and fertilizers (Colpaert 1999).
Host Associations (if applicable):
Thelephora terrestris has a broad host range. It is best known to associate with conifers in the genera Pinus (pines) and Picea (spruces), and with Pseudotsuga menziesii. T. terrestris also colonizes hosts in the genera Quercus (oaks), Alnus (alder), Populus (cottonwoods, poplar, aspen), Salix (willows), Castanea (chestnut), and Fagus (beech) (Colpaert 1999; minnesotaseasons.com).










Fig.1. observations of T. terrestris in Washington State, recorded in iNaturalist.

title: Thelephora terrestris
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA:
Thelephora terrestris is seen year-round, but the main fruiting season is June through early/mid November (iNaturalist.org, research-grade observations).
Seasonal Notes:
Peak fruiting months seem to be August through October. 2025 Observations starkly increased from ~200 in July to ~600 in August, maintaining a steady high until October, then dropping back to ~200 in November (iNaturalist.org).










Fig. 2. relative frequency of T. terrestris seasonal fruiting in Washington State, expressed as proportion of iNaturalist observations by month.

title: Thelephora terrestris
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function:
Thelephora terrestris are ectomycorrhizal fungi (EcMF) with moderate to low saprotrophic capacity (Kanunfre & Zancan 1998; Colpaert 1999; iNaturalist.org; mushroomexpert.com). Given their ability to persevere in a variety of harsh conditions, T. terrestris are primary symbiont colonizers–also known as pioneer mycobionts–and aggressively competitive (Marx et al. 1970, Colpaert 1999). Interestingly, in the early 1900s they were characterized as parasites due to instances of fruiting bodies enveloping and suffocating entire seedlings (Colpaert 1999). Nursery managers inoculate seedlings with T. terrestris with caution because they easily outcompete other EcM species (ibid).
Substrate / Decomposition Role:
Thelephora terrestris can tolerate a wide range of soil types, but seems most dominant on disturbed soils, often low in humus and high in acidity, and can tolerate dry or wet conditions. It is commonly found in disturbed sites, as discussed above (Marx et al. 1970, Colpaert 1999). T. terrestris is known to produce exolaccase, which breaks down lignin (Kanunfre & Zancan 1998).
Interactions:
Thelephora terrestris produce and exude mycotoxins that confer pine hosts protection from Phytophthora cinnamomi, a soil-borne oomycete (iNaturalist.org). Phytophthora are destructive plant pathogens that cause root rot and eventual dieback of the plant. T. terrestris has also been observed to support seedling tolerance to stressful environmental conditions in disturbed habitats such as sites high in tephra (Colpaert 1999). Peterzk et al. (2016) described a dsRNA virus (T. terrestris virus 1) that infects T. terrestris. Not much is known about the effect of this virus on T. terrestris. T. terrestris’ aggressive mycorrhizal ability is a double-edged-sword, presenting a challenge for other ectomycorrhizal species that colonize T. terrestris’ hosts. T. terrestris has been observed to easily outcompete other EcM species (Colpaert 1999).
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators:
T terrestris is generally a very tolerant species. They can tolerate soils with high or low nitrogen, periods of flooding in soils, and have shown to be fairly tolerant of high concentrations of zinc and copper. T. terrestris is, however, very sensitive to cadmium. Lack of T. terrestris in disturbed sites may indicate high levels of cadmium. T. terrestris is also fairly sensitive to competition, and tends to be less dominant in soils with indigenous mycorrhizal species present (Colpaert 1999).

title: Thelephora terrestris
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA:
Widespread and abundant (burkeherbarium.org; minnesotaseasons.com; iNaturalist.org).
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list):
It does not appear to be a species of concern at a state or federal level (ibid).
Threats / Pressures:
No information could be found, probably because it is quite a resistant species.
Management or Monitoring Notes:
It is a species of interest in nurseries due to its ability to confer a greater level of protection to seedling and adult hosts, for the myriad of reasons discussed above (Colpaert 1999). It has also been widely used in forest restoration projects. However, its competitive potential is of note, as it can be problematic when trying to innoculate species with a variety of EcMF (ibid).

title: Thelephora terrestris
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity:
Does not seem to be edible (burkeherbarium.org; minnesotaseasons.com; iNaturalist.org). Undesirable ecause of its tough texture (first-nature.com).
Traditional / Cultural Uses:
Unknown or not recorded.
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds:
Unknown.
Cautions / Warnings: None.

title: Thelephora terrestris
text:
8. References / Further Reading
Colpaert, J. V. (1999). Thelephora. In J. W. G. Cairney & S. M. Chambers (Eds.), Ectomycorrhizal Fungi Key Genera in Profile (pp. 325–345). Springer. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-662-06827-4_14
Common Fiber Vase (Thelephora terrestris). (iNaturalist.org). Retrieved October 25, 2025, from https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/118102-Thelephora-terrestris

Kuo, M. (2015, December). Thelephora terrestris. Retrieved from the MushroomExpert.Com Web site: http://www.mushroomexpert.com/thelephora_terrestris.html
Marx, D. H., Bryan, W. C., & Grand, L. F. (1970). Colonization, isolation, and cultural descriptions of Thelephora terrestris and other ectomycorrhizal fungi of shortleaf pine seedlings grown in fumigated soil. Canadian Journal of Botany, 48(2), 207–211. https://doi.org/10.1139/b70-031

Virology, 489, 12–19. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.virol.2015.11.009

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text: Date: October 13, 2025

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text:
1. Taxonomy & Nomenclature

Scientific Name (current): Pyronema omphalodes
Synonyms / Former Names: Pyronema confluens, Aleuria omphalodes, Humaria omphalodes, Peziza confluens, Peziza omphalodes, Peziza rosella, Pyronema marianum, Tapesia omphalodes
Common Name(s): Does not have a widely recognized common name
Taxonomic Authority / Citation: Does not have a widely recognized common name Taxonomic authority: First discovered by Pierre Bulliard in 1790 and named Peziza omphalodes. In 1870, Leopold Fuckel built on Bulliard’s description, and the species was renamed Pyronema omphalodes.
Higher Classification (Kingdom / Phylum / Class / Order / Family): Kingdom Fungi, Phylum Ascomycota, Class Pezizomycetes, Order Pezizales, Family Pyronemataceae

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text:
2. Morphology & Identification

Fruiting Body Description: salmon pink to bright orange, bumpy, growing in dense clumps disc- or cushion- shaped, hairless fruiting body
Cap / Pileus Characteristics: No cap
Gills / Pores / Spines / Teeth / Etc.: N/A
Stipe / Stem / Attachment / Ring / Volva / Base: No stipe
Spore Print Color: White
Microscopic Features (if available): Spores smooth, ellipsoid, and lack lipid droplets
Other Diagnostic Characters: Grows in recently burned areas
Similar Species / Potential Confusions: May be confused with other species within the genus such as P. domesticum, but can be differentiated from P. omphalodes because it has larger spores and marginal hairs.

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text:
3. Distribution & Habitat in Washington

Range (counties or regions): Primarily in Western Washington with a few scattered sightings in the east
Geographic Distribution in WA: Found in previously forested areas after burns, and in areas popular for camping
Elevation Range: N/A (not enough info)
Habitat Types / Substrate Preferences: Pyronema omphalodes is typically found in post-burn forests or intact forests with campfires/burn pits that have burnt woody residue. They can also sometimes be found in greenhouses on steamed soil. The fungus feeds on burned soil and woody debris, such as charcoal and ash.
Host Associations (if applicable): No host

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text:
4. Seasonality & Phenology

Months of Fruiting in WA: Pyronema omphalodes can be seen fruiting most often in spring, as well as in August and September. The late summer sightings are the result of post-forest fire fruiting, which tends to occur about 1-2 weeks after the original burn.
Seasonal Notes: Pyronema omphalodes peak fruiting times tend to follow forest fire temporal patterns. The fungus tends to only appear in areas where the fire was most intense, resulting in small, congested masses at these microsites.

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text:
5. Ecology & Role

Ecological Function: saprotrophic fungus
Substrate / Decomposition Role: Found in post fire environments on burned soils. They play a key role in fire succession however this role is not fully understood. There is still ongoing research regarding how these Fungi are getting their carbon however there is strong evidence to suggest that they are using pyrogenic organic matter. By decomposing pyrogenic organic matter they are allowing this carbon to be available for plants whereas it would have been locked up otherwise. This allows for reintegration of other species of plants and animals after a fire because of increased nutrient availability. They also help with soil aggregation which is crucial after a fire because it prevents erosion.
Interactions: N/A (no information)
Environmental Sensitivity / Indicators: Indicates a recently burned area

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text:
6. Conservation, Abundance & Threats

Abundance / Rarity in WA: Not abundant under normal circumstances, but it becomes extremely abundant and dominant in the soil fungal community following a fire. This species dominates soil fungal communities within weeks to months after fire. It is a pyrophilous fungi
Conservation Status (state, federal, red list): Ranked as “Not of concern,” this species is not threatened nor is it a concern
Threats / Pressures: Loss of habitat. Since Pyronema omphalodes has a very specific habitat for growth conditions, if post-fire environments and fire frequency was reduced, there would be less available habitat for Pyronema omphalodes to grow in.
Management or Monitoring Notes: Pyronema are not a cultivated species or invasive in environments; they’re lifespans are short-lived and coincide with post-fire recovery. It’d be best to ensure their survival in a post-fire environment due to their abilities to aggregate the soil, decompose charred material, sequester carbon, and capture transient nitrogen pulses after fire.

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text:
7. Use / Ethnobiology / Toxicology

Edibility / Toxicity: There’s no definitive answer on whether or not to eat Pyronema omphalodes, but most answers lead to no. They are not poisonous, but not recommended for consumption. While not poisonous to humans, there is no extensive research on the toxicology of P. omphalodes, so the toxicity to other organisms is unknown.
Traditional / Cultural Uses: Unknown
Medicinal / Bioactive Compounds: Mycrosporine compounds present: mycosporine glutamine (helps promote cell proliferation and repair skin damage from photoaging), normycosporine glutamine, and glucosylmycosporine glutaminol. While these specific compounds benefit the Fungi, there’s no evidence that they benefit humans.
Cautions / Warnings: When looking for P. omphalodes, be cautious when entering areas with recent fire activity. Live embers or damaged snags could pose a fatal threat to your well-being.

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text:
8. References / Further Reading

Key Literature Sources: Filialuna, O., & Cripps, C. (2021). Evidence that pyrophilous fungi aggregate soil after forest fire. Forest Ecology and Management, 498, 119579. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.foreco.2021.119579
Fischer, M. S., Stark, F. G., Berry, T. D., Zeba, N., Whitman, T., & Traxler, M. F. (2021). Pyrolyzed Substrates Induce Aromatic Compound Metabolism in the Post-fire Fungus, Pyronema domesticum. Frontiers in Microbiology, 12. https://doi.org/10.3389/fmicb.2021.729289
Field Guides / Online Resources:
Pyronema omphalodes - mushrooms of Eastern Texas. (2019). Texas Mushrooms. https://www.texasmushrooms.org/en/pyronema_omphalodes.htm
Pyronema omphalodes. (2025). INaturalist. https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/384023-Pyronema-omphalodes#status-tab
Pyronema omphalodes. (2025). Englishfungi.org. https://www.englishfungi.org/Species/Pyronema%20omphalodes
Pyronema omphalodes (Bull.) Fuckel 1870 - Encyclopedia of Life. (2025). Eol.org. https://www.eol.org/pages/160287
Pyronema Omphalodes. (2019). Pyronema Omphalodes. Google Docs. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1169WIyBhetaam7bxmiZ5mzEqXbczuZbP4UXUJC3TJvA/edit?gid=0#gid=0
Herbarium / Specimen Records (if applicable): N/A

title: Pyronema omphalodes
text:

Fruiting Body Photos:



Pyronema omphalodes from above. Bright orange and lumpy; Photo credit: M. Wood




The mycelial network of Pyronema omphalodes found by turning over the charcoal it was growing on; Photo credit: F.D. Springwood
